title: Trump sends Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu a 70th birthday letter writing 'you are great!'
text:
President Trump has sent Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu a 70th birthday letter, thanking him for his 'loyal friendship' and adding 'you are great!' in his own handwriting.

Trump wrote the note to Netanyahu on Monday telling him that 'there are many more victories to come'.

The US president also thanked his Israeli counterpart who he described as 'one my closest allies' for 'your strong leadership and loyal friendship'.

Netanyahu then shared a copy of the letter on Twitter yesterday, thanking Trump.

Earlier this month, Trump received widespread ridicule for his informal letter to Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan as his forces prepared to cross the border and invade northern Syria.

The Israeli PM wrote in a caption alongside his letter: 'Thank you to my friend President Trump for your warm words on my birthday. Our alliance and friendship have never been stronger.'

President Donald Trump embracing Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, as Vice President Mike Pence looks on, in the Diplomatic Reception Room of the White House in Washington in March

In Trump's letter to Netanyahu, the US president wrote 'you are great!' in black Sharpie next to his signature

Trump wrote in the note: 'There has never been a more productive time in the Israeli-American partnership, and I know there are many more victories to come.

'Thank you for your strong leadership and loyal friendship. You are one my closest allies, and I look forward to the continued success we will have working together.'

The president then added along with a message written in black Sharpie, 'you are great!'

Trump's letter of support came after Netanyahu announced he is unable to form a ruling coalition after the most recent elections.

On Monday evening Netanyahu said he could not form a new government following a deadlocked September poll.

This opened the door to his main rival, centrist Benny Gantz, to try and form a government.

Gantz has not revealed his strategy but is expected to invite Netanyahu to join him in a national unity coalition, as long as he vacates the office of prime minister.

But Netanyahu, who celebrated his 70th birthday on Monday, is not ready giving up the reigns of power.

Benjamin Netanyahu (left) and President Reuven Rivlin at a funeral ceremony yesterday. He thanked Donald Trump on Twitter for his letter of support

Trump also wrote an informal letter to Turkey's president Erdogan in which he tried to persuade him not to invade northern Syria, later adding, 'I will call you later'

On October 9 Trump tried to cajole his Turkish counterpart, into negotiating with Syrian Kurds instead of invading, a letter released by the White House reveals.

The president wrote: 'History will look upon you favorably if you get this done the right and humane way. It will look upon you forever as the devil if good things don't happen.

'Don't be a tough guy. Don't be a fool!' he wrote, before adding, 'I will call you later.'

Trump told reporters during a press conference at the time that he hadn't given Erdogan 'a green light' for Turkey to invade, and claimed releasing 'a very powerful letter' would dispel misconceptions about the impact of his troop withdrawal from Syria days before he wrote it.

Trump's liberal use of a Sharpie, as seen in his latest correspondence with a world leader, has caused controversy in the past.

In the lead up to Hurricane Dorian last month, Trump demonstrated to reporters on a map the storm's path as heading towards northern Florida and parts of Georgia.

The president had earlier claimed parts of Alabama were in the hurricane's trajectory, but the original map issued by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), did not show Alabama being in its path.

At a press conference Trump appeared to have made his own alterations to the weather map, showing the storm passing over Alabama.

Reporters picked up on the difference between the two maps and dubbed the 'doctoring' of the map the saw the state now circles in black as 'Sharpiegate'.
description: President Trump wrote a birthday note to Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu telling him that 'there are many more victories to come'. He also added 'you are great!' in black Sharpie.
